abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Urgent Electricity
            Rehabilitation Project for Rwanda were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory; the risk to development outcome was low
            or negligible; the Bank's performance was satisfactory;
            and the Borrower's performance was also satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: supply side and demand side
            should be tackled together to enhance outcomes. Early
            acknowledgement of shortfalls in project design and
            proactivity can ensure realism. Decentralization of project
            supervision: in countries and sectors with limited
            experience and institutional capacity, the World Bank group
            can provide considerable value added by decentralizing
            project supervision and implementation support resources to
            country offices. The bank as well as borrowers should be
            realistic about the time it takes to initiate and complete
            project activities, taking into account the implementation
            capacity of the borrower and the potential technical
            challenges in project implementation.

abstracts.cdata!:
This results profile talks about
            Electricity Rehabilitation Project in Rwanda. International
            Development Association (IDA) funds and expertise have
            contributed to addressing the severe power shortages in
            Rwanda by financing the construction of a new 21 megawatt
            (MW) power plant and the upgrading and rehabilitation of the
            transmission grid infrastructure around the capital, Kigali,
            adding a new main substation and improving the city
            sub-transmission system, serving an overall of 500,000
            people in the capital area. The Urgent Electricity
            Rehabilitation Project (UERP) investments contributed to
            improve the supply and eliminate load shedding with
            electricity supply to be increased.

Rwanda - Urgent Electricity Rehabilitation
            Project : resettlement policy framework

abstracts.cdata!:
This Resettlement Policy Framework (RPF)
            defines the process for selection and approval of
            compensation due to project affected people (PAP), based on
            the Urgent Electricity Rehabilitation Project needs for land
            acquisition and likely impacts, and outlines the eligibility
            criteria for defining the categories of PAP. For property
            owners, loss of land and other assets will be compensated
            with land replacement at new sites, including replacement
            costs at full replacement value without depreciation values
            for physical structures losses, while crops will be paid at
            market values. Food will be provided during construction of
            the new site. Residential or business structure losses will
            be compensated at full replacement value, without
            depreciation, while lost rental income, will be paid in a
            lump sum cash payment of six months rent per tenant, and
            moving expenses will be provided. Assistance for loss of
            rental accommodations will be compensated at six months rent
            to cover moving disturbances. Concerning encroachers and
            vulnerable groups, assistance will be provided in securing
            other access to land for crops growing, subject to approval
            of local authorities/communities. Street vendors on the
            right of way will be allowed access to other site/locations,
            while food and employment opportunities with civil works
            contractors will be provided. Finally, squatters losing
            their shelter will be compensated at full replacement value
            for physical structures and reallocated to new sites, with
            payment of site rents. Cash compensations will be calculated
            in Rwandese Francs, adjusted to inflation, while in-kind
            compensation may include items such as land, houses, other
            buildings, building materials, seedlings, agricultural
            inputs, and financial credit for equipment. Other assistance
            may include moving allowance, transportation, and labor.

repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - Urgent Electricity Rehabilitation
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urgent Electricity Rehabilitation
            Project (UERP) for Rwanda intends to rehabilitate and
            establish new transmission and distribution networks for
            electricity in Kigali and precisely in Gasabo district with
            the sole purpose of increasing access to electricity to the
            residents of Kigali thereby enhancing growth and trade
            through energy access. Negative impacts include: destruction
            of vegetation and crops, temporary and permanent land loss,
            localized soil erosion, localized dust related and noise
            impact during construction, borrow pit impacts, workers
            health and safety, bird strikes/collusions, and aesthetics
            and visual related impacts. Mitigation measures include: 1)
            avoid siting lines through protected areas, other
            environmentally sensitive areas or through mature forest
            stands; 2) string conductors under tension to minimize
            potential damage to remaining ground vegetation; 3) borrow
            pit areas (if any) should avoid other non site areas; borrow
            areas should be reworked to blend into the surroundings.
            Re-vegetation should be performed using local plants. All
            slopes and working surfaces should be returned to a stable
            condition; 4) the entire workforce of the plant should be
            trained in the use of protective gear, handling of electric
            safety equipment, fire protection and prevention, emergency
            response and care procedures. Training given to the
            employees should be backed by regular on- site training in
            safety measures; 5) the construction site for the 4 mini
            substations must contain fire fighting equipments of
            recommended standards and in key strategic points all over
            the site. At minimum at least, carbon dioxide systems, and
            portable fire extinguishers should be installed in the cabin
            construction site; 6) the contractor should engage a refuse
            handling company to remove the wastes from the site to the
            recommended waste disposal site; 7) the project routing has
            been designed to avoid any ecologically sensitive areas
            especially wetlands.  In cases where the route will cut
            across a wetland, minimal disturbance should be observed; 8)
            the contractor should aim to keep to areas of lower
            elevation as far as possible, in order to minimize the
            visual impacts associated with the proposed Transmission
            line; and 9) dust-suppression techniques should be used
            along gravel roads, when required.

repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - Urgent Electricity Rehabilitation
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urgent Electricity Rehabilitation
            Project aims to measurably improve the adequacy, efficiency,
            and quality of power supply in the existing network, secure
            Rwanda's future energy supply, by supporting the
            development of domestic resources (methane gas, hydro, or
            other), and, establish a rural energy program framework,
            including rural electrification and traditional fuels.
            Negative measures include: air pollution, noise pollution,
            contamination of soil and ground water sources due to
            accidental or uncontrolled leakage of stored fuels either
            during transportation and/or storage, and aesthetic impact
            on landscape due to transmission grid infrastructure.
            Mitigation measures include: a) monitor air quality and warn
            communities when air commissioning quality is poor and could
            adversely damage their health; b) fuel transportation should
            be safely covered, followed by adequate cleaning of oil,
            and/or lubricant spills. This shall be the contractors'
            responsibility. In accordance with the country's
            environmental regulations, hazardous and harmful substances
            (e.g., asbestos) shall be banned. Working staff will be
            protected with suitable clothing, shoes, and head protection
            gear; c) ensures safe and reliable road transportation of
            fuel. Clean up any leaks. Design safe storage and pumping
            facility for fuel and regular inspection of all piping
            systems form storage tanks to generators; and d) to minimize
            noise disturbances, working schedules should be established
            at daytime hours only.

repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - Urgent Electricity Rehabilitation
            Project : resettlement policy framework

abstracts.cdata!:
This Resettlement Policy Framework (RPF)
            defines the process for selection and approval of
            compensation due to project affected people (PAP), based on
            the Urgent Electricity Rehabilitation Project needs for land
            acquisition and likely impacts, and outlines the eligibility
            criteria for defining the categories of PAP. For property
            owners, loss of land and other assets will be compensated
            with land replacement at new sites, including replacement
            costs at full replacement value without depreciation values
            for physical structures losses, while crops will be paid at
            market values. Food will be provided during construction of
            the new site. Residential or business structure losses will
            be compensated at full replacement value, without
            depreciation, while lost rental income, will be paid in a
            lump sum cash payment of six months rent per tenant, and
            moving expenses will be provided. Assistance for loss of
            rental accommodations will be compensated at six months rent
            to cover moving disturbances. Concerning encroachers and
            vulnerable groups, assistance will be provided in securing
            other access to land for crops growing, subject to approval
            of local authorities/communities. Street vendors on the
            right of way will be allowed access to other site/locations,
            while food and employment opportunities with civil works
            contractors will be provided. Finally, squatters losing
            their shelter will be compensated at full replacement value
            for physical structures and reallocated to new sites, with
            payment of site rents. Cash compensations will be calculated
            in Rwandese Francs, adjusted to inflation, while in-kind
            compensation may include items such as land, houses, other
            buildings, building materials, seedlings, agricultural
            inputs, and financial credit for equipment. Other assistance
            may include moving allowance, transportation, and labor.
